awd_titl_txt: Atmospheric Science and Chemistry mEasurement NeTwork (ASCENT) Workshop; Atlanta, Georgia; May 25-26, 2023
awd_abstract_narration:
The “Atmospheric Science and Chemistry mEasurement NeTwork (ASCENT) Workshop” will provide opportunities for participants interested in energy and land use change, climate change, public health, and/or instrument development to foster future collaborative studies with the ASCENT network. The NSF-funded ASCENT network has been established to provide high quality, long-term aerosol characterization with high temporal resolution. The workshop will allow researchers to identify studies and utilize the network data to advance process-level understanding of aerosol sources, chemical evolution, and subsequent impacts on human health and climate.

The ASCENT workshop will be held at the Georgia Institute of Technology in a hybrid format from Thursday morning, May 25 through Friday afternoon, May 26, 2023. The workshop will be comprised of presentations, facilitated discussions, and breakout sessions. The workshop format is chosen to promote open discussions and informal exchanges that will advance the field and build new collaborations. Workshop participants will come from academia and government laboratories across the U.S. as well as from similar networks operating in European countries. 

The broader impacts of this workshop include the opening up of new research directions that will have a positive, synergistic effect on the efficiency and research progress in the understanding of aerosol sources, chemical evolution, and subsequent impacts on human health and climate. The workshop will also facilitate collaborations and transfer of knowledge between academia, industry, and government, as well as strengthening connections between various measurement networks within the U.S. and internationally.

This award reflects NSF's statutory mission and has been deemed worthy of support through evaluation using the Foundation's intellectual merit and broader impacts review criteria.

por.por_cntn:
A workshop to leverage the NSF-funded Atmospheric Science and Chemistry mEasurement NeTwork (ASCENT) infrastructure was held at the Georgia Institute of Technology on May 25-26, 2023.  Aerosols play a critical role in climate change and air pollution. The new Atmospheric Science and Chemistry mEasurement NeTwork (ASCENT) is a comprehensive, high time-resolution, long-term monitoring network being established in the U.S. for characterization of aerosol chemical composition and physical properties. The goal of the workshop is to discuss future collaborative studies and proposals that leverage the ASCENT infrastructure in order to advance research in atmospheric science, climate, and air quality.

The workshop was well attended (78 in-person and 76 virtual participants registered), representing academic research, national laboratories and government agencies, including the National Science Foundation (NSF), U.S. Environmental Protection Agency (EPA), National Oceanic and Atmospheric Administration (NOAA), Department of Energy (DOE), and National Aeronautics and Space Administration (NASA). As the ASCENT sites are located at existing monitoring network sites, the participation of staff and scientists from these networks strengthened our connections with these networks. Collaborators from the ACTRIS (Europe) network also participated in the workshop, facilitating the transfer of knowledge and strengthening our connections with international atmospheric observation networks.

The workshop was comprised of presentations from ASCENT members, workshop participants, facilitated discussions, and breakout sessions, covering four scientific themes 1) Energy, infrastructure, land use/change, 2) Climate, 3) Health, Environmental Justice, and 4) Instrumentation, Complementary Measurements, Data Analysis.

The workshop promoted the interactions among scientists with laboratory, field, and modeling expertise to stimulate cross-cutting research with the new ASCENT infrastructure and forthcoming data. Building on the success of the workshop, we have 1) developed many new collaborative research ideas with the workshop participants, 2) facilitated co-located measurements with additional instrumentation at selected ASCENT sites, 3) strengthened our connections with various measurement networks for sharing knowledge and experience, 4) organized an ASCENT meeting at the 2023 American Association for Aerosol Research (AAAR) annual conference to share updates for ASCENT and continue to develop new collaborative activities.

The broader impact of the workshop occurred at several levels. The discussions at the workshop and subsequent meetings have facilitated many new collaborative ideas to utilize ASCENT infrastructure and data in the understanding of aerosol sources, properties, and climate and health impacts. The workshop has facilitated collaborations and transfer of knowledge between academia, industry, and government, as well as strengthened connections between various measurement networks within the U.S. and internationally. Further, the workshop brought together senior and junior scientists, which provided networking and career development opportunities for the younger scientists.

Details and program of the workshop are available at the ASCENT website: https://ascent.research.gatech.edu/events/2023workshop
